006056251X|4.0|Finding the perfect balance between character and back story can be a difficult skill to acquire. Kleypas, unfortunately, doesn't quite do that as well in Devil in Winter. This doesn't detract too much from the book, however. As a matter of fact, it comes across as the strongest of the Wallflower series so far (it's the third in a quartet). Fans of Kleypas will enjoy DIW and may potentially agree that it's one of her better books compared to the last couple years of her books.<br /><br />Evie Jenner is the daughter of a notorious boxer and gambler. Her father is dying and Evie's family refuses to allow her to visit him. They've abused her and are now trying to force her into marriage with a cousin so that they can control her father's money once he's dead. Evie sneaks out to visit Sebastian St. Vincent, the impoverished viscount who attempted to kidnap and rape Evie's friend, Lillian Bowman (It Happened One Autumn). She strikes a deal with him: He can marry her and have her money, so long as she's allowed to have her own portion and have freedom to care for her dying father. Oh, and no sex after the wedding night. St. Vincent agrees to the bargain and the story runs full tilt after that.<br /><br />Kleypas does an excellent job of making Sebastian into a rather cruel husband, but the reader can see through his mechanisms and vicious words to the man desperate to push away any hint of caring or love. However, despite the fact that we're told Sebastian was unloved as he was growing up, we still don't see a lot of the reasons as to why he pushes Evie away repeatedly, though his fascination and affection for her are shown pretty early on. Perhaps it is as one of the secondary characters says: Evie is his ultimate fantasy - the good girl he could never hope to obtain.<br /><br />On that note, Evie is as sweet and innocent as they come, with a thread of steel in her backbone that makes her able to handle everything Sebastian dishes. At times, Kleypas pushes Evie's innocence and naivet&eacute; a little too far, but by the end of the book, Evie develops a strong enough backbone and becomes a strong enough character that you admire her and the decisions she makes. However, readers who don't care for the super-innocent heroine may want to pick up a copy at the library before deciding to buy this book.<br /><br />One of the finer touches that Kleypas puts into Devil in Winter is Sebastian's growing sense of responsibility (while first fueled by a hint of greed for money, eventually turns to ownership and pride in what he's doing) with Evie's father's gambling club. From the moment he steps into the club, Kleypas slowly reveals Sebastian's growth as a business owner, and his aptitude for business. You have to admire him as he finds purpose in his life. Kleypas also doesn't allow herself to drag out the whole \\"no sex after the wedding night\\" deal too far or too long. Many books with this plotline mistakenly draw it out so far that you become bored with the varied sexual misses. Instead, she uses it to slowly fuel the sexual atmosphere, but doesn't push it too far before the h/h give in to the mutual desire.<br /><br />I enjoyed this Kleypas much more than the last 6 or 8 books she's put out. It's reminiscent of her earlier books, though definitely sexed up a lot more, but with a h/h I enjoyed reading and learning about. It could have used more backstory on their families to help round out the characters more. But in all, I'd recommend this to any historical romance reader.nnocence and naivet a little too far, but by the end of the book, Evie develops a strong enough backbone and becomes a strong enough character that you admire her and the decisions she makes. However, readers who don't care for the super-innocent heroine may want to pick up a copy at the library before deciding to buy this book. <br /> <br />One of the finer touches that Kleypas puts into Devil in Winter is Sebastian's growing sense of responsibility (while first fueled by a hint of greed for money, eventually turns to ownership and pride in what he's doing) with Evie's father's gambling club. From the moment he steps into the club, Kleypas slowly reveals Sebastian's growth as a business owner, and his aptitude for business. You have to admire him as he finds purpose in his life. Kleypas also doesn't allow herself to drag out the whole \\"no sex after the wedding night\\" deal too far or too long. Many books with this plotline mistakenly draw it out so far that you become bored with the varied sexual misses. Instead, she uses it to slowly fuel the sexual atmosphere, but doesn't push it too far before the h/h give in to the mutual desire. <br /> <br />I enjoyed this Kleypas much more than the last 6 or 8 books she's put out. It's reminiscent of her earlier books, though definitely sexed up a lot more, but with a h/h I enjoyed reading and learning about. It could have used more backstory on their families to help round out the characters more. But in all, I'd recommend this to any historical romance reader. <br />

B000B8QG4A|5.0|Rightfully heralded as one of Disney's best movies, LADY AND THE TRAMP is marvelously restored in this 50 year anniversary edition.  The colors are sumptious, the sound superb, and it just reminds me of when I saw this movie as a child just how great these early animated efforts truly were.  The endearing spaghetti BELLA NOTTE sequence is more lovely than ever; those evil little Siamese cats and there WE ARE SIAMESE tune even more devilishly clever. And Peggy Lee's HE'S A TRAMP is still doggone great!  All the characters, from Trusty to Jock to Jim Dear and Darling never looked better.  This is truly a film all families should share together; in view of today's CGI animation (which is mindboggling to say the least), this old fashioned animation is just as much fun to revel in!

B00005JOII|3.0|The emptiness at the heart of the protagonists marks this very much as a Woody Allen film.  They, just like the characters portrayed by Allen himself in other films, search art for a moral compass, a compass which they innately lack and which they fear has been lost with the disappearance of religious faith.  In a secular world, Dostoevsky, Sophocles, the visual arts, and Verdi's operas become the territory in which meaning and justice are sought.  While sought, they are not found.  The protagonists see the morality and emotion evident in these works of art, and indeed they see a moral order and emotional bonds in the real people around them, yet they do not feel themselves part of this.  They are not bound as they cannot empathise.  So what they find does not strike them as authentic or authoratative - they remain lost, and without a genuine sense of a cohesive self. <br />* <br />In his funny films it's easy to ignore the empty core of the protagonist - usually a stream of hilarious one-liners offer a disguise as effective as his glaucous horn-rimmed spectacles.  Woody projects the face of a sad clown - a clown that is truly dead-pan, with no real emotion ever creasing his face.  In 'Match Point' Jonathan Rhys Meyers is similarly dead-pan, but to no humorous purpose.  His is the good-looking charm that is a comfort to those around him - they can project their own wishes onto his blank screen.  Thus Emily Mortimer's Chloe can see him as a protege to her own father, along with being her husband and provider of children.  Brian Cox as Alec, Chloe's father and mogul, sees a dependable son-in-law.  Nobody cares to pierce the attractive surface and investigate the chaotic void within - even Chris himself is reluctant to dwell on his own motivations, yet in Johansson's Nola he sees an inadvertant window into a soul not unlike his own, and Nola's reaction suggests a degree of reciprocity - they dive headlong into each other, thinking like Narcissus that they are seeing another being, when in reality they can only see themselves.  As in so many Allen films the female love interest is depicted as in some sense mentally unbalanced.  This can, and often is, read as simple misogyny;  yet perhaps it falls to the woman to dramatise the inner torment of the male lead - just as Chris Wilton can't master, or even bear scrutinising, his own demons, so Woody casts his into the female roles he writes - one can call this swinish, but it is so in the Biblical sense as well as the chauvinistic. <br />* <br />Both Meyer's and Johansson's characters cannot love.  Lust and the quest for worldly approval they can muster, but not love.  Again in an Allen paradigm, they cannot develop a relationship beyond the initial sex-driven courtship.  When forced to do so by pragmatic concerns, in this case Meyer's need to secure wealth and privilege through marriage, the experience becomes dulled and alien.  Meyer's Chris can see the emotion alive between the Hewett family members, but he views this as a spectator, through a metaphorical pane of glass - and he is not so much envious as baffled, bewildered by the fact that he cannot feel emotion in the way they do.   <br />* <br />To be cursed by such an incapacity of feeling and such a fractured sense of self can be a torment.  In the psychiatric literature, which Allen might well be familiar with, these disorders are sometimes attributed to a deprivation of unconditional love and of affirmation during certain stages of childhood development (the film does not have space to explore these causes, but mention is made of family traumas, particularly on Nola's side).  Unsurprisingly, those afflicted often have troubled interpersonal relationships, and some seek professional help - with varying degrees of benefit.  In the film, it is possible to think of the startling denouement as Chris Wilton's attempt to rid himself of his own inner torment - of course a literal interpretation, in terms of the mechanics of the plot,is also sustained - the apparent emotion he displays in the wake of this might be taken as grief for the loss of a part of himself, as literal self-destruction.  The idea that Chris does not differentiate himself fully from Nola, that they are in a distorted sense two aspects of one being, could also stand a Jungian reading - although I'm not sure it would be very illuminating.  <br />* <br />'Match Point' also has a riff on luck's part in life.  It adds a little to the narrative, but not much.  More interesting is the strange perspective from which the English class system is viewed.  The whole upper class scene is viewed as at once removed from the world and deeply exploitative of it - as patrons of the arts the Hewetts have no direct experience of the suffering depicted in the works which they sponsor and view.  Allen has transplanted the affluent New York scene, which he knows well, and dressed it in British trimmings - this should not work, but the extent to which it does emphasizes the point that all privilege commits similar sins.  In any case, the country manors and exclusive tennis clubs and rich drapery give the film a slick sheen. <br />* <br />As cinema, 'Match Point' is a cold experience.  The loveless characters are difficult to love in turn.  As a dramatisation of psychopathology it is well done, and can be seen as an extension of 'Melinda and Melinda'.  Still, I find Woody in this mood a bitter pill - a few laughs make his misguided existential vacuum a bit less black.  The funniest thing about the film is Chris Wilton's non-existent footwork on the tennis court (followed closely by his forehand).
1400079276|4.0|This is the first Murakami novel I have read. I liked his short stories I read in the New Yorker and initially and periodically I was disappointed with the novel, tried to put it down more than once, parts of it were boring, the prose was pedestrian, the work seemed more like a comic book than a novel, I got tired of long descriptive passages, I didn't like the lectures, I wondered about all the product placement, like ads, but I plowed on. I tossed it in the trash and then retrieved it, there was something drawing me to it, maybe the mystery of life. I finally finished it, didn't care for the ending, but couldn't imagine how to end something like this. I didn't want to like this novel, I generally don't like fantasy although I like good science fiction. And when I was finished with it I threw it in the trash again! It's like I was having a love affair with this book and was going through all the stages, romance, disillusion, desire, and reality, no one and nothing will ever live up to our expectations and this book didn't either, and yet, after I finished it I couldn't get it our of my mind. I felt like I was a character in the novel living the same kind of hallucinatory reality, not being able to make sense out of anything, dreaming in a waking state. If that is any indication of the success of this work than it succeeded infiltrating my consciousness and taking possession of me. I think I have found a potato chip author, I have to have another one and will probably have to read everything he's wrote. Not that I'll like it, I'll muse and grumble about him, his simple minded philosophy, his lack of genuine erudition, his poor writing style, grade school level. I will think of Jerzy Kosinski and Marquez, and Lewis Carrol all far superior writers, I will resent Murakami's immense success, but I will probably go on and read everything he's wrote and for the life of me I won't know why. I have been hypnotized--isn't that what life's all about?
B00000DHRX|5.0|This 2CD set collects just about every successful song by leading British 80's/90's pop star George Michael. It is excellent value, as you get 29 songs on two discs, nearly all of which were chart hits between 1984  and the release date of November 1998. <br /> <br />This set is definitely worth 5 stars !!! <br /> <br />George Michael was so popular because he had an excellent singing voice, could write beautiful slow ballads as well as funky, sensual grooves, and had a nice way with emotive lyrics. Everything he touched turned to platinum in the 15 years covered by this set. <br /> <br />Here are just a few standout GM tracks: <br /> <br />You Have Been Loved - Superb sensitive and heartrending slow tune about the demise of a close friend. Simply beautiful. <br /> <br />Faith - Snappy, irresistible 3 minute pop song went to #1 everywhere. One of his best career hits <br /> <br />Freedom '90 - Really groovy , funky track with lyrics that tell the tale of George's ascent to stardom and his early 90's decision to skip the popstar limelight for a more authentic singer-songwriter persona. Excellent. <br /> <br />As - I love this duet cover version of Stevie Wonder's great song , featuring US soul singer Mary J. Blige. Excellent vocal pairing. This song was George's last 90's hit. <br /> <br />Praying For Time - Slow paced serious tune from the Listen Without Prejudice album in 1990. Really good lyrics. <br /> <br />Careless Whisper - Hit #1 in September 1984 at a time when George was riding a huge wave of popstar adulation as part of Wham! A regretful love song with a super saxophone bit in it, that I have always really liked. This song was at #1 on the Australian chart the very first week I ever listened to our local radio chart countdown, so I remember it well. <br /> <br />Outside - George goes disco and liberates himself from a mid 90's career hiatus with this stomping 1998 chart hit.  <br /> <br />One More Try - Soulful power ballad . George proved here what a soulful voice he has , and this went high on the US R&B charts in 1988 - a rare feat for a white European performer. <br /> <br />The Strangest Thing - I really like this 1996 song from the Older album. Intriguing lyrics and a melancholy feel but a great track. <br /> <br />I Knew You Were Waiting (For Me) - Worldwide 1987 #1 hit with Aretha Franklin providing the soul and George carrying on with his unstoppable popstar form. A nice song. <br /> <br />A Different Corner - This was George's first real solo tune and it is marvellous and is a really heartfelt sentiment. A beautiful song, this personal ballad reached #4 on the charts in June 1986. <br /> <br />Jesus To A Child - An elegy to a deceased partner, this graceful tribute made the #1 position in January 1996 - the first new GM record for over 3 years. It marked the end of his self-imposed exile while his court battle with Sony was played out.  <br /> <br />Fastlove - Mid-paced sensual groove that was George's 6th and, to date, final Australian #1 hit in May 1996. A cruisy ode to 90's romantic hedonists, it samples 1982 hit Forget Me Nots (Patrice Rushen).  <br /> <br />Star People - George trashes vain, self-obsessed celebrities on this 1997 hit off the Older album, and supplies a groovy funk beat. <br /> <br />Fantasy - Little known 1990 B-side gets a remix and new production for this set, and is a danceable funk tune that I always liked. <br /> <br />Father Figure - US #1 hit tune from the Faith album that was a lyrical and melodic winner for George in his Grammy award winning annus mirabilis of 1988. <br /> <br />Kissing A Fool - Delightful jazz-influenced melodic track with excellent vocals from George. The 6th (!!!) hit singe from the Faith album, it hit US #5.  <br /> <br />There are plenty of other good GM album tracks I 'm not going to talk about here - try his other 5 studio albums out to hear them. Suffice to say that if you like George's music, you should definitely own a copy of \\"Ladies And Gentlemen\\"if you don't already !!

B000E0OBK6|5.0|Jarhead isn't your typical combat action-war film. In fact it's probably the most unconventional war drama out there. There are no scenes of action, combat, or firefights, and you'd think that that would make Jarhead a boring and uninteresting war film. Well the answer is strangely No. Jarhead does have a moment or two where boredom settles in briefly, but the film is never really uninteresting. The film is based on the book, of the same title, written by former Marine Anthony Swofford (played here by Jake Gyllenhaal). Anthony enlists in the Marines hoping to make something out of himself. He goes through basic training; where he practices and becomes a top ranking sniper. He develops a \\"taste\\" for what they call the \\"pink mist\\", that's a head shot, or kill shot for those of you who were wondering.<br /><br />Once he and his platoon are finished with Basic they're shipped off to Saudi Arabia where they wait for action... and then they wait some more, and then some more. The lack of action and the soldier's lust to \\"get some\\" is eating them up inside. They're bored, and they've been highly and thoroughly trained for combat, but the waiting game is killing them. The war is being mostly fought and won by the \\"zoomies\\" (that's what the Marines call fighter jets). The soldier's are not only suffering from boredom, but also from sexual frustration. They all wonder if their girlfriends are cheating on them, or will dump them. They seem to have very little belief that they'll remain faithful to them while they're away at war, and a couple of them aren't, as can clearly be seen in one particularly shocking scene. There's also another pretty shocking nightmare scene that puts the Nirvana song Something in the Way to great use.<br /><br />Jarhead is less about fighting a war, and more about a soldier's mental state while at war, especially when dealing with the itching nerve to want to be in the middle of combat putting your skills to the test. It can drive some men mad. Jarhead isn't about politics, it's about men, not exactly soldiers (they're men first, soldiers second). The first half of Jarhead is almost a comedy, with a number of goofy moments and dark humor. Then the film slides into the surreal as men are riding on the edge of battle. The scenes with the burning oil fields is darkly haunting and at the same time beautiful. Jarhead isn't Black Hawk Down, it isn't a film about diving into chaos and rescuing your buddy, it's about the way men are in the places and situations of war. The film delivers a number of strong performances from good actors surrounding Gyllenhaal, like Jamie Foxx as Staff Sgt. Sykes (he plays his role very realistically and funny) and Peter Sarsgaard as Troy, Swofford's closest friend.<br /><br />Director Sam Mendes (American Beauty and Road to Perdition) has created the first real war film that fully immerses the viewer in what it's really like to be a soldier, but surprisingly without any combat, and somehow it still succeeds. I should also mention the film's score by Thomas Newman, like all of his scores, is absolutely sensational, and really helps set the tone and rhythm. The film's unrestraint, unflinching look at male soldiers is strangely unique and fascinating. Most war films have a particular message to tell you, in Saving Private Ryan it was the shocking brutality of war, and in Black Hawk Down it was what drives men to go into dangerous, chaotic situations, but in Jarhead I'm not so sure there's a message to learn. Jarhead is more like real life, it's pointless, and it's more of an experience and a state of mind than a lesson. It's a story about men in uniform, and the uniform doesn't change anything, they're still a man underneath. If Mendes has said anything in Jarhead it's \\"once a solider, always a solider\\". You take those experiences with you, and no matter what you do with the rest of your life you'll always be a soldier. The main thing I said to myself after watching Jarhead was, \\"Well, thatwas surprisingly different... and good.\\" And sometimes different is all a film really needs to be in order to work, and Jarhead works. This is one of my favorite films of the year, and one of my favorite war films, right along side Saving Private Ryan and Black Hawk Down., that was surprisingly different... and good.\\" And sometimes different is all a film really needs to be in order to work, and Jarhead works. This is one of my favorite films of the year, and one of my favorite war films, right along side Saving Private Ryan and Black Hawk Down.
0743454537|4.0|I found this to be a very readable, very interesting book. Perhaps my own life entrenched next to my mother, watching her go in and out of hospitals, in and out of treatments and transplants and so on, helped taint my liking for this book a little, but it remains decent. <br /> <br />The book has a very basic plotline: Anna, sick of being poked, prodded, stuck, and hospitalized -- and otherwise ignored by her parents -- seeks out an attorney to declare herself medically emancipated from her parents. The story is told from the point of view of Anna, her mother, father, delinquent brother, attorney, and guardian ad litem (who just happens to be her attorney's ex-girlfriend, of course!). Not once do you hear the voice of Kate, the dying sister -- until the last pages of the book. <br /> <br />Despite everything else I'm going to say, I found myself really enmeshed in the characters. I liked Anna, applauded her, wanted to slap her.... pretty much the way an adult feels about any 13-year-old. I felt for Kate, obviously, and all the medical problems that plague her body -- but I also felt for Anna and Jesse, the two kids often left forgotten in the wake of the latest medical crisis. Despite how much I disliked their decisions, disapproved of how they treated the other children, I also felt sympathy for the parents of these children, Sara and Brian. <br /> <br />The book explored the large range of emotions each character goes through -- the dawning understanding of the parents that they no longer have anything to talk about except their daughter's illness, the \\"acting out\\" of the brother Jesse, since that's the only way he gets any attention, to the time spent when Anna and her father just sit and watch the stars. <br /> <br />I have two issues with the book, however. The first is sheer length -- the book seemed stretched sometimes, like taffy, making it longer but leaving it with less substance to cover the occasional melodrama or confusion. The second is the ending. I don't dislike the ending, but I'm very mixed in my emotions. I spent so long reading the whole buildup of the book and I realize that, while real life would *never* have ended the way this book ended, but in the book, it was oddly satisfactory. Unlike life, the book had a final measure of closure not found. <br /> <br />If you have the time, I reccommend reading the book, despite my lukewarm rating. I did enjoy it -- but I have no intention of reading it again.

B000E97X66|5.0|Finally a Springsteen live set actually worth the price of admission.  So far we have \\"Live/1975-1985,\\" which, despite its husk, is quite uneven.  Then we have a spate of 90s (\\"MTV Plugged\\") and 00s (\\"Live in New York City\\") concert albums which present the \\"grown up\\" Springsteen, nowhere near as ebullient as he was purported to be back in his \\"Born to Run\\"/\\"Darkness at the Edge of Town\\" heyday. <br /> <br />Fresh off the recording and release of the \\"Born to Run\\" album, Springsteen and the E Street Band play inspired music here.  Each instrumentalist shines.  The best thing about this release, especially for people just dabbling into Springsteen's more obscure material, is it shows just how great a guitarist he can be.  Tracks like the \\"E Street Shuffle\\" and \\"Kitty's Back\\" show their ability to play tightly and loose at the same time, something I'm sure a group like the Dave Matthews Band would be jealous of.  The \\"Born to Run\\" material is really focused, with \\"Jungleland\\" being the stand out. <br /> <br />This disc is recommended for anybody whose tired of being disappointed by all the hype surrounding Springsteen's live shows and the uneven official releases documenting them.  \\"Hammersmith Odeon London '75\\" is the real deal.  If you like this and have some extra money to spend, get the \\"Born to Run\\" 30th Anniversary set, which includes this performance on DVD.

B000001DTM|5.0|Ok, this is going to be the most dramatic, emotional, different, and cheesiest review you'll ever see me write; but I mean every last word. Achtng Baby: where U2 was at their finest, where they showed the world that they could do the unbelievable, where they showed that a bands' finest work is often their most underrated masterpiece(like Yes's Relayer). I can use all the fancy adjectives I want, but they will never explain how incredible Achtng Baby truly and really is.<br /><br /> What is it that makes Achtung Baby really stand out and above all the other U2 albums? For one thing, it was where each member got to show how talented all four of them were. The Edge already proved what he could do with the guitar on The Joshua Tree(in my opinion), but this is where he placed himself as one of the 10 best guitar players EVER. Bono wasn't an oustanding singer in U2's beginning(it was U2's energy on stage that got them started), but with each record he managed to improve. Thanks to Achtung Baby, he made his voice one of the most recognizable voices in rock. Adam was a very crappy bassist in the beginning, but like with Bono's singing, he managed to improve with the passing of each new album; but on achtung Baby, he proved how amazing he's gotten. Larry-well, let's face it-is a pretty terrible drummer, but he seem to improve a little on this album. All of this makes Achtung Baby amazing. This and the song quality.<br /><br /> Zoo Station blew me away after I heard it, and even though I wanted to hear it again, I felt it was better that I just listen to the rest of the songs. After every song, I kept wanting more and more. Even Better Than the Real thing was also incredible, if not as outstanding as Zoo Station, but still great. Song after song whirlwinded me into a state of awe and amazement. I couldn't get over how oustanding and beautiful it was. Achtung Baby is not only the U2 at their finest moments, but it is one of the best rock records that ever were. It's not challenging or hard to listen to, it's just great. Every minute is U2 that you wish you could hear in every record.<br /><br /> What interests me hear is how underrated Achtung Baby is. Don't get me wrong, The Joshua Tree was great, but compare it to this masterpiece? Don't even go there! If you think about it, a band's best album is usually their most underrated. Think about it: Yes~Relayer, Santana~Moonflower, Nirvana~In Utero, Joni Mitchell~Court And Spark, and U2~Achtung Baby. These were all artistic masterpieces that got nowhere near as much credit as they deserved.<br /><br /> Zoo Station, mysterious Ways, Ultra Violet, So cruel, and all of the songs for that matter are amazing. Each and every second of Achtung Baby is genuine beauty that you'll never hear in any other record. You must get this right away. it is a work of art that belongs in everyone's collection. Do you have good taste in music and don't own this? Then you need to slap yourself, grab some cash, go to the nearest Target, and by Achtung Baby-NOW.<br /><br /> Sadly, however, in my opinion, this is the last outstanding and really great U2 album. Everything after it is unfocused and boring(although, with a few good moments here and there).to listen to, it's just great. Every minute is U2 that you wish you could hear in every record.     What interests me hear is how underrated Achtung Baby is. Don't get me wrong, The Joshua Tree was great, but compare it to this masterpiece? Don't even go there! If you think about it, a band's best album is usually their most underrated. Think about it: Yes~Relayer, Santana~Moonflower, Nirvana~In Utero, Joni Mitchell~Court And Spark, and U2~Achtung Baby. These were all artistic masterpieces that got nowhere near as much credit as they deserved.     Zoo Station, mysterious Ways, Ultra Violet, So cruel, and all of the songs for that matter are amazing. B000001DWG|5.0|The genius of Mother Love Bone cannot be underestimated, the beauty of singer/lyricist/poet Andrew Wood's timeless lyrics and over the top but excellent vocal delivery combined with Stone Gossards amazing riffs and Jeff Aments incredibly groovy basslines make this a lost treasure from the magical decade known as the 90's.     Its just an utter tragedy Andy Wood didn't live on and fulfill his destiny as Gen-X's Robert Plant, yes, the band had the potential to be that good, with hardrockers \\"This is Shangri-La\\", \\"Come Bite The Apple, Capricorn Sister\\" to soul wrenching ballads like \\"Bone China\\", \\"Stargazer\\", \\"Man of Golden Words\\" and of course, the immaculate \\"Crown of Thorns\\".     It was obvious this band was set to become a huge commodity as the decade began and subsequently would have went on to even greater fame as part of the \\"seattle four\\" when Nirvana changed the perception of Alternative rock forever and brought Seattle based rock bands mainstream.     Unfortunately, things didn't work out that way as Wood was found dead in his apartment from a fatal heroin overdose a month before the release of their debut LP \\"Apple\\", thus ending what would have been one of the most important bands of the generation, and beginning the start of the 90's biggest north american rock n' roll band, Pearl Jam(though i love Pearl Jam just as much and i recommend Ten just as much). \\"Stardog Champion\\" offers you the complete MLB package, as it contains the Apple LP as well as a few bonus tracks and the Shine EP.     Its such a shame things ended the way they did, Andrew was a man who had the charisma and lyrical prowess to go as far as he wanted, and would have been an instrumental figure in Gen-X as an almost poet of sorts, in the vain of Jim Morrison, just someone who believed in the philosophy love and poetry, bottom line, pick this up, i cannot praise this album enough, light years better than the garbage thats being passed off as \\"genius\\" today (Green Day, Nickelback, Coldplay, Arcade Fire etc.) Its just a shame, there was still so much more music left to write.     HIGHEST RECOMMENDATION
078322608X|5.0|This film is essentially based on the absurd idea of time, the idea that time is real, a dimension, which could be travelled through. The NSTP (Non - Spatial Thinking Process) theory, a major part of superultramodern science, suggests that time, like space, is not real, but is rather a mere form of illusion to non-spatial mind. Present is an experience whose physical/material bases are non-spatial feelings. Past, like space and time, is a mere feeling; not any concrete reality existing on its own. To be precise, past is a feeling I have that I felt/had it before. I can't even be sure that something happened in the past. Maybe it's just my feeling in the present, where present is also a feeling. Getting into the past therefore means having the right ideas (that would also exist as non-spatial feelings) that conceptually correspond to the past. And the means to do this is to, at least partly, investigate the design of the universe (probably written in the form of some central superhuman thoughts existing as non-spatial feelings) by say meditation. The film is thus flawed based on a flawed scientific idea. But still I rate this film 5 star as it is thought- provoking and may lead one to superultramodern science and deeper philosophical/scientific problems.         <br /> <br />

B000035Z1Z|5.0|What is a romantic comedy without Meg Ryan?  Not quite the same and that is why \\"French Kiss\\" works.  Meg's character of Kate is very similar to her Sally Albright of \\"When Harry Met Sally\\" - - very stiff, predictable, a bit standoffish and definitely proper.  With another actress playing either part, the character might not garner much sympathy.  And if the audience does not like Kate (or Sally, for that matter), the movie simply would not work.   <br />Fortunately, Meg is made for Kate.  Her inate cuteness makes her a very likable character, and despite seeing her flaws early in the film, you just KNOW that she has something special under her skin, just waiting for the right person to bring it out. <br />Which is definitely and obviously not Charlie (Timothy Hutton), her staid fiance, who leaves on a business trip to Paris without her (she suffers a tremendous fear of flying) and before you can say \\"viva la France\\", he promptly falls in love with the French and lovely Juliette, who apparently has nothing to do but walk around as Charlie's arm candy.  Charlie calls Kate to break off their engagement and despondent, she forces herself to fly to Paris, desperate to save their relationship.  En route, she encounters Luc (brilliantly played by the extraordinary Kevin Kline), a French thief, returning to Paris with the intention to use an unwitting Kate as his mule.  Having her luggage stolen requires Kate to join forces with Luc (she, to find Charlie and woo him back; he, to find her stolen luggage and keep an eye on his smuggled goods).  As they travel through France, with Luc instructing Kate on how to win Charlie back and lighten up, and trying to outrun and outsmart the French police, lead by Jean Reno, Kate begins to rethink where her affections lie. <br />All in all, I absolutely LOVE this movie!  Kevin Kline is wonderful, as always, and he and Meg Ryan have a genuine chemistry and affection.  This is a feel good film, a light romantic comedy with stunning and beautiful scenery.  If you love France, this is a gorgeous love letter to the country. <br />As an added bonus, the soundtrack is equally as fabulous. <br />Highly recommended. <br />
B000E1MTXQ|4.0|The pluses outweigh the minuses in \\"The Bourne Supremacy,\\" which is a good thing because both sides of the scale here are pretty significant. I am not sure if the credit for the pluses goes more to novelist Robert Ludlum for the novel \\"The Bourne Supremacy\\" or to Tony Gilroy for the screenplay, but I know that the writing is the best part of this summer 2004 thriller. I have not read any of Ludlum's books, but I know Gilroy did the adaptation of \\"Dolores Claiborne,\\" so it could be either of them. I also know that the parts of the film that take away from \\"The Bourne Supremacy\\" can be laid at the feet of director Paul Greengrass.<br /><br />The one thing we know about a Jason Bourne film, as opposed to a James Bond film, is that somebody is always out to see him dead. Bond as least has a mission that has people trying to kill him; Bourne is on a hit list just by breathing. Matt Damon plays Bourne with a understatement that marks him apart from the rest of his secret agent brethren, and which also serves to emphasize the strength of the script. Introduced to the character as a badly wounded body floating in the Mediterranean who did not remember who he was, Bourne survived his first film never finding out his real name, just his identity as Jason Bourne, and dropped off the face of the earth to try and live happily ever after with Marie (Franka Potente), his unwilling ally and now only confidante.<br /><br />Of course, they are doomed, and Bourne goes off to get the people who are trying to get him. This becomes somewhat confusing because the people out to get him on one continent are not same people trying to get him on all the other ones. But the important thing is that Bourne goes off to deliver payback and what is great about this character is his economy of effort. Jason Bourne can create a time bomb in thirty seconds using only three things and in his hands a bottle of vodka has a multitude of uses. Every time he gets into a sticky situation you know he is going to doing something smart and he is going to do it quickly. The intelligence of the character and the script is the strongest part of the movie.<br /><br />But at the same time the script is delighting my brain director Paul Greengrass is trying to turn my stomach. Too much of this film is done by a hand-held camera, rarely to any great effect. Then there are the smash cuts and heavy editing of the fight scenes. What is the good of choreographing a one-on-one fight scene if all we get are quick impressions of what is going on. Then Greengrass starts throwing things together, so that we have hand-held shots of moving people cut at warp speed. This gets a bit disorienting at times and can provoke feelings of queasiness. But Bourne's intelligence overcome these visual liabilities.<br /><br />Bourne is also the smartest person in the film, something it take CIA station chief Pamela Landy (Joan Allen) a while to understand, even though Ward Abbott (Brian Cox) and Nicolette (Julia Stiles) both explain this to her repeatedly. The end game of the film actually has a series of levels, so that it is not a simple thing to get everything resolved, and Bourne does have a hand in everything that happens. There is a strong thread of realism going throughout the impossible situations, but that is why the future of the Bourne series is different from the fate of the Bond flicks. \\"The Bourne Supremacy\\" also gets points for the scenes in the movie that we see in the trailer are better in the movie than they are when cut together in the trailer.going to doing something smart and he is going to do it quickly. 1582432678|5.0|I just finished reading \\"We Need to Talk about Kevin\\" and had to fight an instinct to look for an article on Kevin and Eva on the Internet. That's how real this book is. The clarity of the author's voice, the progression of events and the tone of the novel are structured so perfectly that it's almost as though you are reading someone's long ago abandoned diary with yellowed pages. What makes this book so powerful is that it unflinchingly takes you to a dark place and confront the painful and, yes, helpless reality of what these character's are facing. But when you get through this emotional roller coaster, you feel incredibly rewarded to know that there is a novel this well written out there on the bookshelves. <br /> <br />Some have criticized the fact that Franklin seems so passive in light of the horrible things his son is doing. But people who make those criticisms should ask themselves whether, when faced with the option of facing up to the evil things their child is doing or simply refusing to accept them, they would not make the same choice. As for the big climax, this is one thing in the book that I feel was a mistake. It was unnecessary and the author would have achieved her vision without it. I think the most heartbreaking and brilliant part of the novel are the last four pages. I don't usually reread books, but I read these last few pages several times because they were so poignant and combined together so many emotions: pity, despair, hopelessness, forgiveness and even hope. I've only cried at the ending of two books: one was by Ernest Hemingway. The other was by Lionel Shriver.

B00005JOFO|5.0|The Movie: <br /> <br />Brokeback Mountain is about two men who work together one summer in extreme isolation. They form a deep bond during their time there and eventually sleep together. Because homosexuality is not accepted in their time and place (1960's Wyoming), they deal with conflicted emotions and go their seperate ways into marriages. While married, they reunite from time to time, taking trips to Brokeback Mountain where they continue an on-again, off-again affair lasting several years. <br /> <br />The two men feel differently about their relationship. Ennis (Heath Ledger) cannot bring himself to terms with it, and feels that it must always be hidden, in the shadows. His marriage suffers cruelly from it. Jack (Jake Gyllenhaal), however, wants to embrace their relationship more fully (ironically, perhaps, he has the better family life, though it is always hollow for him). Ultimately, their relationship ends tragically. Ennis' family dissolves and Jack is beaten to death on account of his homosexuality. <br /> <br />The film is quiet and powerful. The score and backdrops are sweeping and majestic. The acting is top-notch. The direction, excellent. The emotions, real. However one feels about the subject matter, this is a great film. <br /> <br />Its Reactions: <br /> <br />I have found the reactions to this film to be quite surprising. Friends, of whom I had never suspected any sort of bigotry, refused to go see it and only spoke of it with either irony or derision in their voices. And we can see in the reviews of this film here on Amazon (and the helpful/unhelpful votes) that it has provoked something intense and deeply-seated in many people. <br /> <br />It is my opinion that love is love (though, so the reader understands my personal context, I am both a straight man and politically conservative). I understand that some others feel that the portrayal of homosexual love is part of some \\"agenda\\"--they call it propaganda--but I don't think that, just becausea movie presents a different point of view than your own, it makes it somehow sinister or manipulative. I hope that everyone here who takes the time to rate these reviews or write their own has taken time to watch the film, prior to commmenting on it. I think that the film, itself, proves that it is not out to manipulate or \\"change society\\" except in the ways that art always does, by \\"holding the mirror up\\" and allowing us to examine ourselves. <br /> <br />Obviously, this was an important movie to make. The reactions prove it. While I had suspected that society was a little more sophisticated than to go crazy over a film like this, I was wrong. This is a dialogue we need to have. And so, to those who've seen the film and still wish to attack it, I actually want to thank you: while I disagree with what you believe, and the reasons you have for your attacks, its good that we have a chance to talk about it. <br /> <br />Five stars for the film itself and five stars for the important discussion it has launched.

B00006GO9Q|5.0|Miles Davis historians look at this album and at \\"Bitches Brew\\" which followed, and talk of how important these recordings were to Miles' career as a turning point.  This album is the first of Miles' \\"electric period,\\" a highly controversial segment of his career that produced some highly influential, profound music of arguable accessibility.  But what makes this album so incredible is not just how it was a beginning for Miles in fusion; it was the equivalent of the Second Continental Congress for the new genre that would dominate the jazz scene in the 1970s.  One only has to look at the personnel and think for a bit: in addition to Miles, the group consisted of Wayne Shorter on saxophone, John McLaughlin on guitar, Herbie Hancock, Chick Corea, and Joe Zawinul on keyboards, Dave Holland on bass, and Tony Williams on drums.  This is not just a list of the absolute top tier of young musicians of the time; it is literally the core group of EVERYTHING significant that happened in fusion.  Every one of these men with the exception of Dave Holland went on to start a fusion group: Shorter and Zawinul began Weather Report, Hancock started Mwandishi and later the Headhunters, Corea led Return to Forever, McLaughlin started the Mahavishnu Orchestra, and Tony Williams led Lifetime.  Without exception, these groups were the defining forces of fusion (arguably the only ones that truly succeeded).  That's what makes this album so incredible in historical context; anyone who would leave a mark on fusion was here, and anyone who wasn't here...wouldn't.  That's what makes this more than an interesting experiment.  It was the planting of a seed that altered the course of the careers of each musician here. <br /> <br />As for the music itself, the description has been more or less covered by the myriad of reviews already here.  Suffice it to say that it is one of the rare musical documents that can be appreciated on ALL musical levels: there is enough interest in the soloists and group interaction to give it true depth and replay value, it's funky (though not overtly), it's brilliant mood music (as much as I hate that term), and it's even quiet enough to be shoved into the background (though why would you want to?).  My favorite moment is when Tony Williams finally ramps up the groove about 13 minutes into the second track and pushes Miles to the next level of intensity. <br /> <br />Get this album to hear the music which sent forth the new wave of true innovators, arguably jazz's last (at least for now).

0930289234|5.0|There's not a lot to say about Watchmen which hasn't already been said. But, as is so rarely the case, the hype is true. Nothing could possibly be the same in comics after something like Watchmen. The heroes aren't really heroes, but far from being the cookie-cutter antihero, they have surprising depth and emotion. They all perceive the world in radically different ways, and it's apparent in the way Moore writes. For example, Dr. Manhattan, the blue superhuman with the power to manipulate atoms, is narrated like no superhero has ever been before. He exists in several places at once, experiences the future, past, and present simultaneously. He has the power of God. Yet, at the same time, he is so lost in the world, he ends up having to desert it for Mars. And there's not a single moment when the reader won't sympathize with him.<br /><br />The characters are some of my favorites outside of Transmetropolitan. Despite their silly names and costumes (even sillier than the average superhero, if you can believe it), they all have a startling three dimensionality to them.<br /><br />The story is interesting and unique, starting with the murder of one of the few remaining active heroes, The Comedian, (see what I said about the silly names? And wait until you read the comic, he wears a sort of quasi-bondage getup...) which is the obvious inspiration of one of today's most original concepts. ('Powers')<br /><br />From there, it just continues to become more and more convoluted and compelling.<br /><br />Read it for yourself. You won't be disappointed.
0440211727|5.0|A Tme to Kill, the debut novel from Acclaimed writer John Grishman deals with the thinly threaded storylines dealing with a rape and attempted murder of a [young] black girl.  Soon after race issues boil over as protesters on both sides of the fences barrier over the woodwork. Grishman expertly narrarates this complex issue by focusing on the more simplistic, organic notions of the case, and the bodies that are affected by each decision that is made.  True, the ending seems rather rushed and he certainly could of filled another 50-100 pages without question, but in the long run everyone believes that this magnificent story of Racial disharmony in present day and age end up asking, not answering, questions that need to be asked. Grishman was quoted in the reprinted foreword in saying he wouldn't change a word.  With a story like that, you can see that he doesn't need to, compelling storytelling will always be compelling storytelling. In the End Grisham nails it out of the park, and leaves his readers yearning for more.

I have to admit it was rather unique, with a heavy influence from the more classic DC style. However it's painted in watercolor and the contrast and depth of the color is extremely poor. On top of that, it's printed on cheap pulp paper, which is just puzzling: It's just been turned into a huge movie license by the Wachowski brothers, and even says so on the cover. So why would they print their merchandise, so recently equated to printing money, on the lowest-quality paper available? <br />Who knows. Not only are the colors poor, the images tend to fade off. This should be in hardcover with glossy paper and good ink, but it's not. <br />I suggest reading this comic, but I couldn't reccommend buying it, because in its current form, it just won't last.
B00008QSA5|5.0|\\"Super Session\\" still sounds fresh and exciting after 35 years. What makes the album great is the guitar playing -- Mike Bloomfield for the first half, and Steven Stills for the rest. Al Kooper's keyboards and vocals supply the continuity in sound. Bloomfield's playing is among his best recorded work. He sounds like a jazzy B.B. King with his precise, melodic solos. \\"Stop\\" and \\"His Holy Modal Majesty\\" are highlights, but all his songs are excellent. Stills' playing on this album has been underrated by critics. \\"Season of the Witch\\" displays some of his richest playing. Kooper and colleagues' arrangements are inventive and effective, with their rockin' version of \\"It Takes a Lot to Laugh\\" a stand-out. The additional tracks on this version of the CD do not really add to quality of the original, but they do provide some insights into the process of producing the music. For example, after listening to \\"Season of the Witch\\" without horns, one is likely to conclude that Kooper did a great job in including them in the original album. Overall, this is an excellent album, revealing Bloomfield at a high point in his playing (sadly, drugs and other demons would trouble him until his premature death in 1981). Stills' fine guitar playing is also a revelation. And Kooper never had a finer hour on record.

6305428352|5.0|\\"Mr. Holland's Opus\\" is, in my opinion, one of the greatest contemporary classics. This film shows how a teacher can have a tremendous impact on years' worth of students. Richard Dreyfuss is a struggling composer and musician who is \\"dragged into\\" teaching music at a high school. He's filled with hopes and dreams of his own, but the realities of life, large and small, affect him. Even though he has such a passion to strive for greatness of his own through composing and being a musician, his true passion comes out through his teaching. Again, truly how a teacher should be. Mr. Holland not only taught the values and essence in musical education, but the everyday, importnat values in life. He taught the values of determination and courage, like a shy and quiet girl trying her heart out to be great at playing the clarinet, or a distressed ex-football and ex-wrestler student how to play a bass drum. Simple little stuff; well, maybe not little, because as he syas \\"It takes a lot of work to learn a musical instrument.\\" However, a little confidence and determination can go a long way. The different characters of certain students depicted in the film are just examples of how effective this teacher was. A great example is the senior girl who dreams of going to New York to become a famous singer. Mr. Holland realizes that there was truly someone who was passionate about something he could relate with. If it hadn't been for his confidence he instilled, she never would have gone on and pursued her dream. (It would have been nice to have known if she made it or not. Then again, I don't know if it's a true story, but we got to have a little imagination.) It's sad to know that because of some rotten budget, he was cut from his job along with the entire music and arts programs in the school near the end of the story. Still, even though we start to feel that it was all for what, his is a success story, as the generations and years of students who respond to his retirement, particularly the clarinet girl as she became the governor! It seems like all that drive and confidence to get to something like that all lead back to Mr. Holland. To me, there should be so many more teachers like that. Yes, \\"life is what happens to you while you're busy making other plans,\\"; it's true. It was in the students that he inspired and lead to success.

B000002AHC|3.0|'Notorious Byrd Brothers' was released in 1968 as the fifth studio album from The Byrds.  It was the first Byrd album that did not produce at least one Top 40 hit.  The band had scored a run of seven Top 40 singles since 1965, including two number one hits.  Released in 1997, this remastered CD does much to reveal the reasons behind this weak production, and while the bonus tracks are a welcome supplement to the brevity of the album, there isn't enough of value there to save it.  While anything produced by the collective efforts of Roger McGuinn, David Crosby, and Chris Hillman is bound to be revealing of their individual talents, the discord within the band seems to have altered their artistry and even their judgement.  A key point of controversy within the group, for instance, was whether Crosby's risque composition 'Triad' should find inclusion on the disc.  One listen to The Byrds rendition, and comparing it to songs that made the original vinyl (such as 'Space Odessey' and 'Tribal Gathering'), reveals what a no-brainer this was.  Perhaps The Byrds no longer wanted to be counted along with Crosby's peculiarities, but such artistic discord could only lead to Crosby bolting from the band, which he did before the final version of the disc was assembled. <br /> <br />It's rather remarkable that the individual songs themselves reveal a sort of internal discord within the psyche's of the individual members.  'Natural Harmony' for example, a Chris Hillman track, begins with a dreamy, surreal, even jazzy introduction, but then turns boldly psychedelic.  'Draft Morning' follows with lyrics addressing the horrors of war, but with a mellow melody and a psychedelic/Sgt. Pepper's sounding use of horns.  There is also great contrast in this song's verses and chorus, and a nice bass line from Hillman picking up a bit of slack in the production.  'Wasn't Born To Follow' follows with catchy vocals and guitar hooks, but with more psychedelic meanderings.  'Get To You' begins witha beautiful medody underlying the initial verses, then serves up a disjointed chorus.  'Change Is Now' begins as an undistinguished ballad, lulling one into drowsiness, then launches into a psychedelic guitar-fest.  'Old John Robertson' starts out as a folk ballad well-suited to one of The Byrds first two albums, but sports an unusual, classical bridge.  More juxtaposition awaits on track nine, 'Tribal Gathering', moving from lounge-style ballad to an engaging discharge of heavy metal music.  'Dolphin's Smile', another Crosby track, is another whistful ballad interupted by psychedelic eruptions.  Add to these tracks the horn-laden discourse on amphetamine abuse, 'Artificial Energy', and the first bonus track, Roger McGuinns 'Moog Raga', a mind-meld of sitars and synthesizers, and you have one of the most unusual collections of songs to be found anywhere in the annals of rock.  Then there's the instrumentals, 'Bound To Fall' (an interesting, and entertaining track, which eventually wound up in the able hands of Stephen Stills and Manassas), and a demo of 'Change Is Now', titled 'Universal Mind Decoder'.  Just to completely confuse the situation, all of the barely managed chaos is completely tamed by the presence of not one, but two versions of Carol King and Geoffrey Goffin's nostalgic 'Goin' Back', perhaps the one song on the record deserving of a spot in the Top 40. <br /> <br />While this album offers a number of quality tracks, it feels like a puzzle with male and female dovetails that don't quite fit with one another.  It seems everyone is going in a different direction, and while most of the band may be content to work with one another, they don't seem to be working together.  The depth of the discord is vividly revealed in a hidden track at the end of the disc, a studio altercation between Crosby and drummer Michael Clarke, who can't seem to get the beat Crosby is looking for, and who can't seem to care less.  There are more 'F-words' used than in Freddy theFreeloaders family.  Despite the many drawbacks, the disc does come handsomely packaged, as are all of The Byrds remasters.  I suppose this is rock and roll history, which isn't always a pretty picture.
B000B8IA2G|1.0|Stargate: Atlantis is amazing. Buy it. But not here, or anywhere else in Canada. Due to a mix up, Stargate: Atlantis was incomplete, as the contents on disk one are also on disk five. The problem is non-existent on the US release, so order this from an American source.
078324228X|3.0|I actually give this movie two separate ratings. First, solely as a cinematic and artistic story I give the movie a 4, maybe even a 4.5 but as some of the other reviews have pointed out, there are some very large historical inaccuracies. Here is my review on each: <br /> <br />Movie: <br />As a movie \\"The Hurricane\\" is excellent. Denzel Washington does a great job as do the other actors in this film. It is definitely a tear jerker and helps portray racism which WAS very prevalent during the civil rights movement era. The movie is entertaining and enjoyable, the problem lies with the claim that it is a \\"true story.\\" The best part of the movie is that it exposes horrible corruption,but when that corruption is possibly false, the movie loses credibility. If it had a different title and was described simply as a story, none of these issues would exist. <br /> <br />The Facts: <br />I am not a lawyer, or a judge, or anything that has to do with crime. I am an officer in the US Army and hopefully someday a business executive. Therefore, I can not give any \\"facts\\" regarding the case. Having said that, there is much controversy over what actually happened. It is definitely true that the image of Rubin Carter in real life differs from what is depicted in the movie as well as the image of his friend, John Artis. What the movie doesn't say is that Carter WAS in fact a criminal before he ever was accused of committing the triple murder, one of his crimes being the brutal beating of three people. Additionally, Carter was court marshaled 4 times and was kicked out of the Army after serving only approx 21 months.  After released from prison, friend John Artis was arrested again and convicted for dealing drugs (cocaine.)  <br />Artis and Carter were never declared innocent of the murders, they were released from prison due to an error in the judicial process. I do not know whether Carter and Artis are guilty or innocent and I encourage anyone who becomes interested to do theirown research. Be careful what site you get your info from...\\"graphic witness\\" for example has been accused of being racist. Check the article about Carter on Wikipedia, it seems more reliable and is from a more trust worthy source.  <br />Lastly, we need to remember that there in fact was much racism in this country at the time and to some degree there still is. Often people don't like to admit it. The truth is that racism may or may not have played a part in Carter's trial and he may be innocent, but he may also be guilty. Either way the movie definitely has some factual errors but hey, it's Hollywood, I mean, the true story of U571 is that the British stole the Enigma machine, unlike the film, the American's were no where to be found. <br />Take Hollywood with a grain of salt and enjoy the movie as it is a great piece of entertainment and features some excellent actors giving heart touching performances. <br />

B000AMJDHY|4.0|With all of the accolades piled on by Alt Press (et al) and the CD wrapper's sticker praising the disc with \\"some of the best melodies\\" one can find, at $8 this was seemingly a steal. This CD falls somewhere between foo fighter-eqsue meets broadway, or erasure with a guitar section. Definitely catchy, albeit weird at times, the CD unfolds like a theatrical production i haven't heard except on, well, musical soundtracks. After several listens through, I began to latch on. The intro song is a waste of 36 seconds but the 2nd tune (The Only Difference...) is definitely one of the disc's catchiest in a rock n'roll-way. The synth vocals on #4 (Tacks for Breakfast..) and the keyboard riff got embedded in my head for days. The lead-in on #5 (Camisado) and lick are hard to drop, but the lyrics (\\"bop bop ba dohdoh\\", \\"youve earned your presence at the ICU hall of fame\\") add a thick layer of cheese. A catchy #6 draws on the band's androgeny (\\"boys will be boys baby...\\") and has a classic vegas-esque shout-out (\\"when i say shotgun you say wedding\\"). #7 (Lying is the Most Fun...) comes off like a cabaret soap opera complete with octave spanning vocal lines (\\"haaaaaarlequin girls....\\"). The story line on #10 (I Write Sins...) is clever and the chorus rocks along with the whiney lyrics and xylophone background. The \\"almost-talking\\" singing of 12 and 13 arent the strongest on the CD, but somehow seem in context for the rest of the music. Bottom line, this is an interesting debut from these guys (their website is also clever) which sort of defies any label. Is it pop? Is it punk? It's definitely worth a listen.

Although initially a controversy, \\"Like A Prayer\\" was finally accepted as a classic and to many is her best album. \\"Like A Prayer\\" shows great diversity in styles and themes, the songs are each different and most important of all, amazingly well-written. This album really affirmed my faith in Madonna, even during the 80's she made good music, contrary to critical belief.<br /><br />Earlier on I stated that there was some initial controversy over this album, mainly the lead single \\"Like A Prayer\\". The video featured Madonna dancing on hill of burning crosses and a black Jesus, personally I see nothing wrong with a black Jesus, aren't Christians all for racial equality and acceptance, but I can see why the burning crosses were offensive, the producer/director of that video didn't need to use visual blasphemy to sell a video.<br /><br />Now onto the album, the opening title track is an amazing song that deals with love and religion heavily. It is a far different version to the remix on \\"The Immaculate Collection\\" and in my mind is far better, the guitars sound really authentic and fresh for the late 80's. \\"Express Yourself\\" brings some fun to the album with it's signature 80's beat and that hit factor. It talks about a man expressing himself and a woman putting their love to the test.<br /><br />\\"Love Song\\" is best described as an art-funk/old-school track and is basically a collaboration with Prince. Madonna would use some lyrics from this track in about 16 years for her monster club-hit \\"Hung Up\\". It seems a bit off-beat for me but lovely nonetheless. \\"Till Death Do Us Part\\" is probably the best track on the album tied with \\"Oh Father\\". It has a very nice beat and chorus. Madonna's voice is superb, this song is about her marriage to Sean Penn.<br /><br />\\"Promise To Try\\" is a lovely ballad written about dealing with her mother's death. It's a sombre ballad but has a lovely piano and string instrumentation. Overall, a beautiful track. \\"Cherish\\" brings the listener back to happiness and the 'pop' Madonna. This song was a big hit when it was released and has a superb black and white video. It makes reference to Romeo and Juliet and is about cherishing your lover.<br /><br />\\"Dear Jessie\\" seems a little out of place on the album with it's child-like feel, it sounds like a nursery rhyme set to music. It's a very lovely track and should've been included on her greatest hits to show her diversity as an artist.<br /><br />\\"Oh Father\\" is a phenomenally good track with an overall sad tinge, it sounds like an ode to a dead father, I don't really know though. The song is amazing, the vocals show her range and the song is really well produced.<br /><br />\\"Keep It Together\\" brings back the funk while still having a serious message. The song sounds so modern, strangely not dated. It's basically an ode to her family situation. \\"Spanish Eyes\\" is this album's \\"La Isla Bonita\\" and shows off her fondness towards the Hispanic culture. Her vocals are really strong.<br /><br />\\"Act Of Contrition\\" is a short experimental track to end. It's a great neo-instrumental. I don't get it's purpose though.<br /><br />Overall, this album stands as one of Madonna's best, while the critic's favourite it still doesn't surpass \\"Ray Of Light\\". The songs are brilliant, without sounding dated and show her maturity and willingness to experiment with her music. This album is a must for any Madonna or 80's music fan, without it the 80's wouldn't have been the same and Madonna deserves huge credit and shouldn't be shunned.ling with her mother's death. It's a sombre ballad but has a lovely piano and string instrumentation. Overall, a beautiful track. \\"Cherish\\" brings the listener back to happiness and the 'pop' Madonna. This song was a big hit when it was released and has a superb black and white video. It makes reference to Romeo and Juliet and is about cherishing your lover. <br /> <br />\\"Dear Jessie\\" seems a little out of place on the album with it's child-like feel, it sounds like a nursery rhyme set to music. It's a very lovely track and should've been included on her greatest hits to show her diversity as an artist. <br />\\"Oh Father\\" is a phenomenally good track with an overall sad tinge, it sounds like an ode to a dead father, I don't really know though. The song is amazing, the vocals show her range and the song is really well produced. <br /> <br />\\"Keep It Together\\" brings back the funk while still having a serious message. The song sounds so modern, strangely not dated. It's basically an ode to her family situation. \\"Spanish Eyes\\" is this album's \\"La Isla Bonita\\" and shows off her fondness towards the Hispanic culture. Her vocals are really strong. <br />\\"Act Of Contrition\\" is a short experimental track to end. It's a great neo-instrumental. I don't get it's purpose though. <br /> <br />Overall, this album stands as one of Madonna's best, while the critic's favourite it still doesn't surpass \\"Ray Of Light\\". The songs are brilliant, without sounding dated and show her maturity and willingness to experiment with her music. This album is a must for any Madonna or 80's music fan, without it the 80's wouldn't have been the same and Madonna deserves huge credit and shouldn't be shunned. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

0767805712|3.0|Director:  Andrew Niccol <br />Cast:  Ethan Hawke, Uma Thurman, Alan Arkin, Jude Law, Gore Vidal, Xander Berkeley, Jayne Brook, Elias Koteas. <br />Running Time:  106 minutes <br />Rated PG-13 for brief violent images, language, and some sexuality. <br /> <br />\\"Gattaca\\" is intended as a cautionary tale about genetic engineering. The film takes place in a future world, not too far removed, where destiny is determined by genes: all babies (except for a few \\"accidents,\\" known as \\"invalids\\") are genetically engineered to near-perfection, people are hired on the basis of their genetic profile, and the imperfect products of accidental births are relegated to low-status menial jobs. Our hero, Vincent Freeman (Ethan Hawke), is an \\"invalid\\" who wants to rise above his genetic destiny. So, in an elaborate scheme, he buys the identity of Eugene Morrow, a genetically perfect athlete crippled in an accident, and gets the job he always dreamed about in a space-exploration program.  When the director of the Gattaca Aerospace Corporation is murdered; however, investigations into the crime put into question Vincent's true identity, and he soon finds that his long deception could be unraveled and his life-long dream could be shot down in flames. With only fellow colleague Irene (Uma Thurman) and Jerome on his side, Vincent must race against the powers that are trying to put him back into the social hole he was supposedly born into and put an end to the life he has worked so hard to build. <br /> <br />The film has a very sorrowful approach to what sounds initially like a very lame plot. It's cinematic and stylistic without being pretentious or overdone, and the way it is shot and put together reflects very well the film's bland and sterilized society in pursuit of perfection. The chilling sense of realism that goes with the world of Gattaca makes everything within it become more than just a strange concept in a science fiction film. Not unlike Spielberg's 'A.I.', Gattaca very cleverly draws from horrors within our society today to suggest the terrifying prospect that our science will eventually render us, as a natural species, obsolete.  Director Andrew Niccol (\\"Lord of War\\") has done a fine job in transforming this sci-fi flick into something much deeper and more interesting. The writing is not spectacular, but is still better than most. Hawke's narration provides very good atmosphere for the film as he talks about the way of the world in this eerie future and the film's theme is very secure, with events such as the murder being practically irrelevant. The thing that matters most is Vincent's dream and the social inequalities that prevent him from actualizing it, and this is made very clear from beginning to end.  The acting performances are all very adequate, but the stand-out ones are Ethan Hawke and Jude Law, who seem so comfortable in their characters and, truth be told, share more chemistry than Hawke and Thurman do. This was one of Jude Law's first feature films, and it is a remarkably impressive debut.  Basically, this is a film that says what it means. Even in a world that has successfully bred perfection, people still suffer, the system is still unjust and lives still go to waste. Far from just being an unrealistic portrayal of what the future will hold, 'Gattaca' questions the ideals of mankind, the principles of civilization and leaves us to wonder what we, as a society are truly striving for.
B0009WFFS6|5.0|I must agree with the majority and disagree with the minoirty: this video record of this special occasion is a pure delight from stem to stern.  I think anyone who does not hear fire is looking too much and not listening enough.  The bass lines are played with feeling and with pure musicality, the interaction between these three old bandmates has actually IMPROVED with time.   <br /> <br />Jack's voice has a lived in quality (as has Eric's) that is also on the records of older bluesman like Howlin' Wolf, Muddy Waters and John Lee Hooker--i.e. those who managed to survive and still make music. <br /> <br />If you are looking for the kind of loud fireworks of earlier days...well those are there too, but in a different way.  The music and the musicians have aged, but as others have pointed out, like fine wine.  This is real music from the heart, head and fingers from three excellent musicians who clearly respect and love each other and the music. <br /> <br />This is NOT a mere excercise in nostalgia, so if you are looking for only that, well you will get a bit of that too, but that does not feel to me what this is about.  It is more about a classic musical trio playing some classic and timeless music.   <br /> <br />The video and sound quality is superb as is the song selection (I like Jack Bruce would have loved if \\"I Feel Free\\" would have been on here, but like him, I cannot see how they could have done that, as it was almost a pure studio creation). <br /> <br />For those people who get the blues, jazz, and the essence of what Cream did and still does, this is a must.

B000001ESP|5.0|People probably think of the Jimi Hendrix Experience and Cream when they think about power trios but Rush has outlasted them both and are still playing some wonderfully complex material that still wins them fans among both the musicians and the casual listener.<br /><br />Speaking as both a guitarist and a great fan of music, I've been thoroughly entertained by Rush for many years and after all this time, \\"Moving Pictures\\" and \\"Signals\\" are still my two favourite albums with the former only just pipping the latter for the title of Rush's best ever album.<br /><br />Neal Peart is quite possibly the world's best drummer and some of the stuff he plays on this album is simply amazing and is close to what you'd call jazz drumming and he plays solely on feel.  Geddy Lee's understated but competent bass work and his distinctive voice is excellent but I suppose as a guitarist, I'm most impressed with Alex Lifeson's work.<br /><br />If you want to hear what great, tight bands sound like, \\"Limelight\\" is a study in what great musicianship and mastery of your instrument sounds like and \\"Tom Sawyer\\" with that incredible intro is destined to become a rock classic.  Not a weak track on this masterpiece and like all classic albums, has to be heard completely at one sitting to truly appreciate its genius.<br /><br />This remastered version is very well done and so the sound quality is a definite improvement over the original.  Very highly recommended to both aspiring musicians and fans who want to hear what truly great music sounds like.<br /><br />Update:<br /><br />The latest SHM-CD mini lp replica sleeve release (mlps) is no appreciable improvement sound quality-wise over my previously reviewed remastered version above but if you are a collector of mlps designs, this particular one comes with a 20-page booklet which contains the track listings and all the lyrics in both English and Japanese as well as a very entertaining write-up by drummer Neil Peart called \\"Moving Pictures: A Rush Newsreel Bylines\\"  as well as a very faithfully replicated inner sleeve jacket and while the cover itself isn't exactly among the best mlps designs that I've ever seen it is still quite good and certainly not the worst.  At least the cardboard used is thicker and of higher quality although the overall assembly still isn't as good as say the recent ones that Sony did for the Michael Jackson and even the REO Speedwagon \\"Hi Infidelity\\" and Men At Work \\"Cargo\\" mlps releases which is what quality mlps designs should look like.  Strangely, \\"Cargo\\"'s mlps design was much, much better than \\"Business As Usual\\"  which shows that if the recording companies really wanted to they could come up with good quality mlps designs for all albums but I guess they do pick and choose which releases to give the first class treatment to and which ones not to although they have the audacity to charge us the same price for both!  The Michael Jackson mlps designs are very, very good though and are a fitting tribute to the late, great King of Pop.<br /><br />Overall, given the price tag you will have to decide if you want to \\"upgrade\\" to the mlps version although if you don't already have a copy of this great album, it may be worth getting this higher priced mlps version but not so much for the sound quality which hasn't been improved upon noticeably from the jewel cased prior remastered version.faithfully replicated inner sleeve jacket and while the cover itself isn't exactly among the best mlps designs that I've ever seen it is still quite good and certainly not the worst. B0000009OX|5.0|music fan said it perfectly: \\"This is the perfect pop record.\\" Discard notions of BARRY MANILOW being pop.  This is pop.  Power pop, a cousin to punk that was raging at the time.  Not hardcore.  VIBRATORS, CLASH, 999.  Those guys were in the general class of this band.  But there was the Irish thing, not that I'm an expert.  And what's particularly amazing about the UNDERTONES is their pure focus on typical teenage pop subjects that you might expect from the BAY CITY ROLLERS.  Because they lived during 'the troubles' with Northern Ireland being occupied by English military and bombings and rotteness like that.  I guess STIFF LITTLE FINGERS lived in the same region and one was Prostant and the other band Catholic and SLF were political in their lyrics.  The UNDERTONES' music was far more tough than the very silly BAY CITY ROLLERS without being harsh.<br /><br />What makes this stuff shine is dual guitars, strong guitar presence and strong song writing.  The odd vocals, well, ya get used to it.<br /><br />The UNDERTONES went through a musical change to something softer and, I guess, in an effort to get more played on the radio and to be more actual pop stars.<br /><br />RED ROCKERS sorta did the same thing, not that many people know of them except maybe if they remember that one off radio hit they had in the early 80's 'China girl' or something.  They were from Lousiana.  The similarity to the UNDERTONES is both bands made incredible first albums then shifted in later albums to, it seems to me, to try to be more radio friendly and to make themselves a career in music.<br /><br />Basically, most punk bands don't make a career in music.  Several punk bands did get signed to major labels in England and I assume several did make a living at it.  Who?  The DAMNED?, the CLASH if they'd not sacrificed themselves financially, I dunno who else, ENGLISH BEAT?, the SPECIALS?, STIFF LITTLE FINGERS?, SHAM 69?.  I don't know.<br /><br />What I do know is that this UNDERTONES album and the 7\\" records that came in the same year or so with it along with their basically equally incredible second album, Hypnotized capture a sound that is never found in any other band: real strong pop carried by a strong guitar sound, tight musicianship and catchy song writing with a vocal that eventually captures your ears and ends up, for the next 25 years, sounding great.<br /><br />If you can use the 'listen' buttons so.  For any song.  I've loved this band since I first heard them and continue today, maybe just a notch slightly less cuz I'm not into hearing the same songs, same versions, over and over.  But I give it some years alone and go back to the stuff and it blasts all over again.  Particularly this album and the very tasty 7\\"s worth of music they've added to this CD.
